VOL. XXXII, No. 44

HOOVER IS ELECTED
BY CAMPUS POLL
Secretary Commerce Wins
Over Tammany Hall
GOVERNOR RITCHIE THIRD
Nearly Five Hundred Votes
Cast by Student Body
Herbert Hoover and Governor
Albert Smith of New:York finished
in the order named in the straw
vote made at Hopkins. The vote,
which was taken in forty colleges
throughout the United -States, was
fostered by The Independent, a
Boston weekly.
The result is the continuation of
a tendency which was shown last
week so that Hoover is snow on the
long end of a 222-127 total in the
bitter contest waged mostly between
Smith and the winner. Since last
Friday Hoover received fifty votes
to Smith's forty-three, Ritchie
polled forty-five additional marks
opposite his name, Reed received
four, Dawes and Lowden each, two
Willis and Walsh, one apiece, and
Curtis has yet to have a supporter
on the campus.
The Totals

These additional votes bring the
totals as follows: Republicans:
Hoover 222, Lowden 14, Willis 5,
Dawes 5, Curtis 0; Democrats:
Smith 127, Ritchie 90, Reed 12,
Walsh 7, and Donahey 1. These
results decrease the lead which
was enjoyed by the Republican
candidates last week. The score,
which was 185 to 141 last week,
is now 246 to 237. Ritchie's
great increase in the number of supporters was the cause of the jump
in the Democrat's favor.
Dr. Mitchell Mentioned

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 27, 1928

Adams Contest Not to
Be Held on Thursday
Originally scheduled to be
held at assembly on this
Thursday, the annual Adams
Oratorical Contest has been
postponed until the first assembly after Easter holidays.
The four finalists who will
compete are: Paul Cordish,
M. D. Ghent, John Norris,
and S. Carson Wasson. The
contest is limited to members
of the Sopohomore Class, with
the winning speaker receiving
a handsome gold medal.

Hopkins To Debate
Lafayette College
A debate with Lafayette College
will be held in the C. E. Hall on
Friday, March 30. The subject of
the debate will be: "Resolved, that
the United States Should Refuse to
Protect Private Interests in Foreign Countries." The Hopkins
team, consisting of Norman Gardiner, William Driver, and W. R. McD6rman, will uphold the affirmative.
The judges for the debate have not
as yet been secured.

News Letter Applies
.For Office Space
Application for quarters in Levering Hall has been made by the
NEWS LETTER. Space in the south
wing of the building was requested
with the staff solidly in favor of
this action. Mr. Schad stated that
this was the first application received from any of the activities.
The Board of Managers, he added,
would meet in a week or so and
take action in the matter then, and
at present he could not see why
there should be any difficulty in
securing the wanted space.

Jere H.Dunne To
Address Assembly
Mr. Jere H. Dunne, vaudeville
actor and manager, will address the
assembly next week. His subject
will be "The Psychology of the
Placing of the Acts on a Vaudeville
Bill." Mr. Dunne, who. was connected with the Keith circuit for
over fifteen years, has played as a
headliner in nearly all the theatres
of the country. The program,
which will include music, will be
of great interest as Mr. Dunne will
probably give one of his singing
and dancing acts.

DR. BEARDSLEY TALKS
ON REAL LITERATURE
Gives Principles of Intelligent
Criticism of Books
"First of all, what is literature ?"
said Dr. W. A. Beardsley in his
talk on "What is Real Literature"
at the assembly Thursday. "There
are two answers. First, literature
is anything which is written—
sounds simple and is simple. Second, literature is anything which is
written; but with a certain meritorious style."
This latter definition has reduced
criticism of literature to the style of
the writing. Style is excessively
varied.; each generation has its
own mode of presentation, its own
idea about style. Take, for instance, old French literature. which
is done in epic form and is highly
characteristic of the civilization of
the Middle Age. That literature
could not be written now, for the
present age is too highly complex
to produce the simplicity of
thought co-lateral to the Middle
Ages.
No more could the type of work
of the Renaissance be duplicated,
for the forces which produced this
latter period are unmatched by any
modern factors. Later we find the
difference between Rabelais of the
Renaissance and the seventeeth
century literature characterized by
Montaigne and his essays.
Then came the court of France
which supported literature. The
style at this period was highly cultured and well developed. Court
life and stories of the wealthier
class predominated. But all this
was overthrown with the court by
the French revolution.
Themes changed, almost overnight, from those of court life to
one expounding against the rich.
From a cultured style the literature
dropped to that of the rabble and
mob. The resolution brings us well
up to modern literature.
Rousseau's doctrines were the
foundation upon which "ego" in
literature bgean ; for Rousseau, like
Voltaire, advocated any man's doing
as he liked provided he did not interfere materiallly with others. Voltaire had started this idea, but his
views needed liberty to allow them
to be carried out. On the other
hand, Rousseau began at the bottom with the axiom that all men
free and that they were inherently
good but deteriorated with each generation.

PRICE 5 CENTS

Juniors to Banquet
On Thursday Night
Following time-proved tradition, the Junior Class will
hold its banquet at the New
Howard hotel on Thursday
evening of this week. The
time has been set for 6.45
P.M.
Chairman Frisch is desirous
of having returns made from
the men appointed in each
fraternity by Tuesday of this
week. The fee has been
placed at $3.00 per plate.
Features of unusual interest
have been provided for by the
committee. Tickets may be
obtained from Frisch, Caplan,
Hecht and other members of
the committee.

CINDER PATH TEAM
HOLDS TIME TRIALS
Scheidt, Yellot, and Pindell
Show Up Well in Heats
The results of the time trials held
last Thursday were disappointing.
This, however, was anticipated, as
the time for the first real tests is
usually poor. Three races were
run on the cinder path. The sprinters stepped off the hundred, while
the distance men ran the mile. The
/110 men and those of the halfmilers who did not enter the mile,
ran the quarter. The time in the
century dash was very encouraging, but the wind was behind the
sprinters and the timers were inexperienced. This event was won by
Pindell, with Lockart a close second.
Workouts at Gilman

All the heats in the 440 were very
close. Two of the three heats were
won by dark horses. Graf stepped
out in front in the first heat and,
with a little improvement in style,
should develop into a very good
quarter-miler. The second heat
was won by Yellott, who usually
runs the half mile. Vernon Scheidt,
as expected, won the third ..heat.
The time in the mile was very poor,
due partially to the heavy wind that
was sweeping over the field. Gwinn
won this event with ease. Either
Ornach or Scheibel will probably
run the mile in the meets with
Gwinn.
Heats Close

The broad jumpers and high
jumpers have been working out
for the past week at the Gilman
Country School under the direction
of Assistant Coach Hambleton.
The pits at the Roland Park institution are in better condition than
those on Homewood field, which
are not expected to be put into condition until next week. Either today or tomorrow trials will be held
at other distances. The dash men
will run the 220 and 440, while the
880 men will have a chance to run
in their own event. The distance
men will have their first tryout in
the two-mile. Towards the end
of the week the high hurdlers will
have their first workouts under the
stop-watch. At the same time the
field men will test their ability.
The competition in the high-hurdle is very close. Vivell, Hershey
and Long are fighting for the two
places open. All three will be able
to run in the first meet at William and Mary, as there is room for
six hurdles on the track at Williamsburg.

CHAMPION CLEVERLY
ACTED AT LYRIC
Enthusiastic Audience Aplauds Players Throughout
Performance
BOYNTON AND HORN STAR
Production Run Off Smoothly
With Feminine Parts All
Well Done
When the curtain fell last Friday
night at the Lyric another triumph
was recorded in Barnstormer history. In fact, if the frequent applause of an extremely enthusiastic
audience was a reliable criterion,
"The Champion" was a marked success by the time it was half over.
This three-act comedy. by Thomas
Louden and A. E. Thomas proved
as palatable to the ticket holders as
any production of former years, if
not more so. The performance as
a whole was run off with a pleasing
finish and self-evident efficiency.
Cues were taken without the the
slightest hesitation and the characterizations were well done. "Pop"
Swindell deserves no little credit for
his able and untiring direction which
produced such fruitful results.
Return of Prodigal is Theme

The story tells of the return of
the prodigal son of an ambitious,
middle-class English family. •Wil-*
liam Burroughs, the prodigal, had
left home on account of his strict
father. Meanwhile the other two
brothers had been carefully groomed
for church and state. Lady Elizabeth Galton, poor but of noble blood,
is engaged to advance them socially.
Then the prodigal returns and upsets all this when it becomes known
that he is "Gunboat" Williams, undefeated lightweight champion of
the world. After a series of sidesplitting incidents, he proves the
making, rather than the breaking,
of his family.
Warfield and White Good

Benny Boynton, as William Burroughs, the champion, and Dwight
Horn, as Lady Elizabeth Galton,
walked off with the honors. Boynton's lines carried distinctly beyond
the footlights and he handled the
comedy situations well. The supporting cast gave a well-balanced
performance. Ridgely yVarfield, as
the father, and Don White, in the
difficult role of George, the monocled and politically ambitious brother, were especially able. Don Strader, Richard Berney, Irving Gordon
and William McDowell gave an accurate interpretation of their rOles.
Desch and Caplan as "Ladies"

The feminine parts were all well
done. Dwight Horn, as Lady Elizabeth Galton, was undeniably fitted
to play opposite Boynton. In fact,
if we had not known that this was
a Barnstormer play, we would have
made a date with "her" Ourselves.
John Disch, as the irresponsible
younger sister, was a close second.
Howard Caplan, in the person of
Mlle. Antoinette, gave an hilarious
burlesque. John Rothschild, as Mrs.
Burroughs, the mother, showed the
results of a careful study of his part.
The settings, done by William
Banks and Clyde Friz, were skillfully executed. The musical program of the Blue Jays between the
acts was most satisfactory.

Hoover and Smith Popular

The Secretary of Commerce and
the New York executive each have
polled more votes, alone, than did
all of the other eight men listed.
Smith's total, which was the lower
of the two, is above the grand total
of the others, excluding Hoover, by
3,077 ballots.
According to the statistics announced, the total number of ballots marked is 27,302. The individual totals are: Republicans:
Hoover 11,727, Dawes 1,732, Lowden 670, Curtis 163, Wills 157
Democrats: Smith 8,260, Reed
1,083, Ritchie 896, Walsh 497, and
Donahey 115.
Colonel Lindbergh, Will Rogers,
and Aimee Semple McPherson
were also suggested as possible
Presidential candidates. Each had
one vote.
The institutions from which returns have been made are: University of Cincinnati, Cornell, Pennsylvania, New York University, Wes-

leyan (Connecticut), Middlebury,
University of Kentucky, University
of North Dakota, University of
Arizona, Penn State, Wellesly, and
Dartmouth. With the exception of
the University of Kentucky and the
New York University, all the above
colleges had a majority of Republican votes. The southern institution's count was 431-186 in the
Democrats' favor. In the New
York institution the count is 1,785,1,493. In only one of the above
did ,Smith go lower than second
place in the Presidential possibility
race. This occurred at Connecticut
Wesleyan College, where Hoover
led, with Reed second. Smith
placed third.

AUDITORIUM THEATRE

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MARCH 27, 1928

INTERCOLLEGIATE
NEWS
Student opinion at Brown is
showing itself decidedly opposed to
the system for athletic managerial
competition which is at present
being used. This fact has been
clearly evidenced in that at this time
there are only seven candidates in
the field competing for eleven managerships, which is an almost unheard-of state of affairs in the modern college where an athletic managership is considered a high award.
Measures are being taken by the
Undergraduate Council to make
the tasks a trifle more pleasant for
the candidates, or "scouts," as they
are affectionately termed.
*

*

*

Extra-curricula activities are
highly regarded by the undergraduates at the University of Kansas,
if we are to believe the results of
a questionnaire which was recently
held to ascertain whether or not
that was the condition. One hundred and seventy-two members of
the student body voiced their opinions as preferring success 'in extracurricula activities to a grade of
"C" in their scholastic endeavors.
Only 118 cast a vote checking the
negative side of this question.
Among the numerous reasons that
Were given for the adoption of this

OLD TRADITIONS MAY FAIL IF JUNIORS
FAIL TO HOLD ANNUAL BANQUET
Another of the old traditions of
Hopkins may go by the board unless the Junior Class members take
immediate steps to remedy the conditions.
Last year the Student Council
promulgated a ruling whereby students in the three lower classes
should pay their class dues at registration. The dues were paid and
forgotten. A month or so ago the
more curious individuals in the
classes, upon making inquiries,
found that the dues, as paid, did
not include admission to the class
banquets. An extra assessment was
to be made to cover the expenses
of these occasions.
Banquet committees were appointed and prices of banquet tick-

ets determined. Then the fun began of trying to collect this money.
The Juniors have been particularly
unsuccessful in their attempts to
extricate the price of tickets from
members of '29. Thus far, not a
single member of the Junior Class
has bought a banquet ticket.
Whether they find it necessary
to recover from the effects of the
"Pow-Wow" or are broke because
of the Barnstormer's annual effort,
the fact remains that unless at least
fifty banquet tickets are sold by 1
o'clock today, the Junior banquet
will be called off and the banquet
season will not have any official beginning. An earnest attempt to
keep from canceling this year's
party will be made by '29 at its
meeting today.

Features Controlling Style Are

The Measure of Oil Value

Nobility Takes Interest

Later, governments and friendly
nobility took an interest. About
two-thirds of the English writers
were supported thus. The nobility
liked to have a poet or a shortstory writer about the house. The
idea behind this support was the
obvious fact that if a writer had a
pension from the ruler he would
hardly write against that government in the fear that the reimbursements would be taken away.
If one wishes to live and write he
must eat, hence economic conditions
play a prominent part in literature.
Other features which control
literature are the heredity, of the
writer, his mental make-up and the
environment in which he is writing.

His Favorite Brand
"It was but recently, when I started to act as master of
ceremonies with my band at theParamountTheatre,that
I realized how vital perfect voice condition was to h performer. I have always been a consistent smoker and for.
tunately, Lucky Strikes were my favorite brand. I like

Pertinent Questions

There are five questions which
are highly pertinent in the judging
of a book. First, who wrote it.
This may sound foolish, but a very
high percentage of those who read
do so without the faintest idea of
who was the writer. It is easy to
determine an author's name and
one should remember it after he
finds it out.
The next query is when did he
write it, for a whole different series
of postulates must be supplied in
order to judge the book by its age.
The third question is why did he
write it. If you are able to learn
why a man wrote a book you have
two-thirds of the knowledge you
need in order to judge it. Take
"Elmer Gantry." Lewis may have
written that for several reasons: he
may have needed money, he might
have written it for the amusement,
or he could have written it because
he detested those who earned their
living by teaching or preaching religion.
The final question is, could you do
better? This is possible, for when
you condemn a book you do so because you have reason to believe
that your opinions or judgments are
better than the authors. Your likes
or dislikes about parts of the book
are also big factors.
;

Number of Books

"But why should I worry whether
or not you like literature ?" concluded Dr. Beardsley. "I don't care
whether you ever read another
book; but in the process of education you cannot avoid them. There
are about 8,000 published a year.
Hence, your are bound to read some.
And as long as you are alive and
read, you should have a basis for
judgment of books. If you are to
pass even one part of Hopkins you
should be a fairly good critic of
literature."

totals as follows: Republicans:

Dawes 5, Curtis 0; Democrats:

results decrease the lead which
was enjoyed by the Republican

DR. BEARDSLEY TALKS
ON REAL LITERATURE
Gives Principles of Intelligent
Criticism of Books
"First of all, what is literature ?"
said Dr. W. A. Beardsley in his
talk on "What is Real Literature"
at the assembly Thursday. "There
are two answers. First, literature
is anything which is written—
sounds simple and is simple. Second, literature is anything which is
written; but with a certain meritorious style."
This latter definition has reduced
criticism of literature to the style of
the writing. Style is excessively
varied.; each generation has its
own mode of presentation, its own
idea about style. Take, for instance, old French literature. which
is done in epic form and is highly
characteristic of the civilization of
the Middle Age. That literature
could not be written now, for the
present age is too highly complex
to produce the simplicity of
thought co-lateral to the Middle
Ages.
No more could the type of work
of the Renaissance be duplicated,
for the forces which produced this
latter period are unmatched by any
modern factors. Later we find the
difference between Rabelais of the
Renaissance and the seventeeth
century literature characterized by
Montaigne and his essays.
Then came the court of France
which supported literature. The
style at this period was highly cultured and well developed. Court
life and stories of the wealthier
class predominated. But all this
was overthrown with the court by
the French revolution.
Themes changed, almost overnight, from those of court life to
one expounding against the rich.
From a cultured style the literature
dropped to that of the rabble and
mob. The resolution brings us well
up to modern literature.
Rousseau's doctrines were the
foundation upon which "ego" in
literature bgean ; for Rousseau, like
Voltaire, advocated any man's doing
as he liked provided he did not interfere materiallly with others. Voltaire had started this idea, but his
views needed liberty to allow them
to be carried out. On the other
hand, Rousseau began at the bottom with the axiom that all men
free and that they were inherently
good but deteriorated with each generation.

PRICE 5 CENTS

Juniors to Banquet
On Thursday Night
Following time-proved tradition, the Junior Class will
hold its banquet at the New
Howard hotel on Thursday
evening of this week. The
time has been set for 6.45
P.M.
Chairman Frisch is desirous
of having returns made from
the men appointed in each
fraternity by Tuesday of this
week. The fee has been
placed at $3.00 per plate.
Features of unusual interest
have been provided for by the
committee. Tickets may be
obtained from Frisch, Caplan,
Hecht and other members of
the committee.

CINDER PATH TEAM
HOLDS TIME TRIALS
Scheidt, Yellot, and Pindell
Show Up Well in Heats
The results of the time trials held
last Thursday were disappointing.
This, however, was anticipated, as
the time for the first real tests is
usually poor. Three races were
run on the cinder path. The sprinters stepped off the hundred, while
the distance men ran the mile. The
/110 men and those of the halfmilers who did not enter the mile,
ran the quarter. The time in the
century dash was very encouraging, but the wind was behind the
sprinters and the timers were inexperienced. This event was won by
Pindell, with Lockart a close second.
Workouts at Gilman

All the heats in the 440 were very
close. Two of the three heats were
won by dark horses. Graf stepped
out in front in the first heat and,
with a little improvement in style,
should develop into a very good
quarter-miler. The second heat
was won by Yellott, who usually
runs the half mile. Vernon Scheidt,
as expected, won the third ..heat.
The time in the mile was very poor,
due partially to the heavy wind that
was sweeping over the field. Gwinn
won this event with ease. Either
Ornach or Scheibel will probably
run the mile in the meets with
Gwinn.
Heats Close

The broad jumpers and high
jumpers have been working out
for the past week at the Gilman
Country School under the direction
of Assistant Coach Hambleton.
The pits at the Roland Park institution are in better condition than
those on Homewood field, which
are not expected to be put into condition until next week. Either today or tomorrow trials will be held
at other distances. The dash men
will run the 220 and 440, while the
880 men will have a chance to run
in their own event. The distance
men will have their first tryout in
the two-mile. Towards the end
of the week the high hurdlers will
have their first workouts under the
stop-watch. At the same time the
field men will test their ability.
The competition in the high-hurdle is very close. Vivell, Hershey
and Long are fighting for the two
places open. All three will be able
to run in the first meet at William and Mary, as there is room for
six hurdles on the track at Williamsburg.

CHAMPION CLEVERLY
ACTED AT LYRIC
Enthusiastic Audience Aplauds Players Throughout
Performance
BOYNTON AND HORN STAR
Production Run Off Smoothly
With Feminine Parts All
Well Done
When the curtain fell last Friday
night at the Lyric another triumph
was recorded in Barnstormer history. In fact, if the frequent applause of an extremely enthusiastic
audience was a reliable criterion,
"The Champion" was a marked success by the time it was half over.
This three-act comedy. by Thomas
Louden and A. E. Thomas proved
as palatable to the ticket holders as
any production of former years, if
not more so. The performance as
a whole was run off with a pleasing
finish and self-evident efficiency.
Cues were taken without the the
slightest hesitation and the characterizations were well done. "Pop"
Swindell deserves no little credit for
his able and untiring direction which
produced such fruitful results.
Return of Prodigal is Theme

The story tells of the return of
the prodigal son of an ambitious,
middle-class English family. •Wil-*
liam Burroughs, the prodigal, had
left home on account of his strict
father. Meanwhile the other two
brothers had been carefully groomed
for church and state. Lady Elizabeth Galton, poor but of noble blood,
is engaged to advance them socially.
Then the prodigal returns and upsets all this when it becomes known
that he is "Gunboat" Williams, undefeated lightweight champion of
the world. After a series of sidesplitting incidents, he proves the
making, rather than the breaking,
of his family.
Warfield and White Good

Benny Boynton, as William Burroughs, the champion, and Dwight
Horn, as Lady Elizabeth Galton,
walked off with the honors. Boynton's lines carried distinctly beyond
the footlights and he handled the
comedy situations well. The supporting cast gave a well-balanced
performance. Ridgely yVarfield, as
the father, and Don White, in the
difficult role of George, the monocled and politically ambitious brother, were especially able. Don Strader, Richard Berney, Irving Gordon
and William McDowell gave an accurate interpretation of their rOles.
Desch and Caplan as "Ladies"

The feminine parts were all well
done. Dwight Horn, as Lady Elizabeth Galton, was undeniably fitted
to play opposite Boynton. In fact,
if we had not known that this was
a Barnstormer play, we would have
made a date with "her" Ourselves.
John Disch, as the irresponsible
younger sister, was a close second.
Howard Caplan, in the person of
Mlle. Antoinette, gave an hilarious
burlesque. John Rothschild, as Mrs.
Burroughs, the mother, showed the
results of a careful study of his part.
The settings, done by William
Banks and Clyde Friz, were skillfully executed. The musical program of the Blue Jays between the
acts was most satisfactory.

INTERCOLLEGIATE
NEWS
Student opinion at Brown is
showing itself decidedly opposed to
the system for athletic managerial
competition which is at present
being used. This fact has been
clearly evidenced in that at this time
there are only seven candidates in
the field competing for eleven managerships, which is an almost unheard-of state of affairs in the modern college where an athletic managership is considered a high award.
Measures are being taken by the
Undergraduate Council to make
the tasks a trifle more pleasant for
the candidates, or "scouts," as they
are affectionately termed.
*

*

*

Extra-curricula activities are
highly regarded by the undergraduates at the University of Kansas,
if we are to believe the results of
a questionnaire which was recently
held to ascertain whether or not
that was the condition. One hundred and seventy-two members of
the student body voiced their opinions as preferring success 'in extracurricula activities to a grade of
"C" in their scholastic endeavors.
Only 118 cast a vote checking the
negative side of this question.
Among the numerous reasons that
Were given for the adoption of this
Preference the most popular were
that activities offered wide opportunities to develop initiative, independence, self-confidence and companionship. All of which only
brings to our minds again the
much-abused question. Just what
is the-primary purpose of a; college
or university today?
*

*

*

Outdoor rough-housing and the
usual absurdities attendant on "hell
week" or informal fraternity initiations are rapidly becoming an affair
of the past. A poll of the presidents of the various Greek chapters at Syracuse University revealed the majority of these officers
as being opposed to sticli a form
of hazing. The belief seems to be
rapidly growing that to cause the
neophytes to appear ridiculous to
the outside world serves only to humiliate the frosh to no effect, and
gives rise to the many current falacious and absurd conceptions of
fraternity life.

classes. When the officials decided

fellow to keep away from the 'infirmary when he said: "It's better

OLD TRADITIONS MAY FAIL IF JUNIORS
FAIL TO HOLD ANNUAL BANQUET
Another of the old traditions of
Hopkins may go by the board unless the Junior Class members take
immediate steps to remedy the conditions.
Last year the Student Council
promulgated a ruling whereby students in the three lower classes
should pay their class dues at registration. The dues were paid and
forgotten. A month or so ago the
more curious individuals in the
classes, upon making inquiries,
found that the dues, as paid, did
not include admission to the class
banquets. An extra assessment was
to be made to cover the expenses
of these occasions.
Banquet committees were appointed and prices of banquet tick-

ets determined. Then the fun began of trying to collect this money.
The Juniors have been particularly
unsuccessful in their attempts to
extricate the price of tickets from
members of '29. Thus far, not a
single member of the Junior Class
has bought a banquet ticket.
Whether they find it necessary
to recover from the effects of the
"Pow-Wow" or are broke because
of the Barnstormer's annual effort,
the fact remains that unless at least
fifty banquet tickets are sold by 1
o'clock today, the Junior banquet
will be called off and the banquet
season will not have any official beginning. An earnest attempt to
keep from canceling this year's
party will be made by '29 at its
meeting today.

Nobility Takes Interest

Later, governments and friendly
nobility took an interest. About
two-thirds of the English writers
were supported thus. The nobility
liked to have a poet or a shortstory writer about the house. The
idea behind this support was the
obvious fact that if a writer had a
pension from the ruler he would
hardly write against that government in the fear that the reimbursements would be taken away.
If one wishes to live and write he
must eat, hence economic conditions
play a prominent part in literature.
Other features which control
literature are the heredity, of the
writer, his mental make-up and the
environment in which he is writing.

Pertinent Questions

There are five questions which
are highly pertinent in the judging
of a book. First, who wrote it.
This may sound foolish, but a very
high percentage of those who read
do so without the faintest idea of
who was the writer. It is easy to
determine an author's name and
one should remember it after he
finds it out.
The next query is when did he
write it, for a whole different series
of postulates must be supplied in
order to judge the book by its age.
The third question is why did he
write it. If you are able to learn
why a man wrote a book you have
two-thirds of the knowledge you
need in order to judge it. Take
"Elmer Gantry." Lewis may have
written that for several reasons: he
may have needed money, he might
have written it for the amusement,
or he could have written it because
he detested those who earned their
living by teaching or preaching religion.
The final question is, could you do
better? This is possible, for when
you condemn a book you do so because you have reason to believe
that your opinions or judgments are
better than the authors. Your likes
or dislikes about parts of the book
are also big factors.
;

Number of Books

"But why should I worry whether
or not you like literature ?" concluded Dr. Beardsley. "I don't care
whether you ever read another
book; but in the process of education you cannot avoid them. There
are about 8,000 published a year.
Hence, your are bound to read some.
And as long as you are alive and
read, you should have a basis for
judgment of books. If you are to
pass even one part of Hopkins you
should be a fairly good critic of
literature."

Dr. Van Orman Goes
On Visit To Ithica
Thursday night Dr. Ray Van
Orman returned to his home in
Ithaca, where he spent his early
life and attended Cornell, becoming
one of star ends on the "Big Red"
team. He graduated in 1908 and
later became line coach there.
In 1920 he came to Hopkins as
coach and has been here since.
During his absence Coaches
Schmeiser and Darley took charge
of lacrosse practice. Dr. Van
Orman returned to his duties yesterday.
